title: Myelopathy — General Evaluation
icd10: G95.89 (Other specified diseases of spinal cord)
scope: ** General myelopathy evaluation — systematic differential diagnosis approach for patients presenting with myelopathic signs and symptoms (upper motor neuron weakness, sensory level, bowel/bladder dysfunction, gait disturbance). Covers algorithmic workup to differentiate compressive (degenerative, neoplastic, abscess, hematoma) from non-compressive (inflammatory/demyelinating, infectious, vascular, metabolic, paraneoplastic) etiologies. Provides initial stabilization and empiric management across all settings. Complements the Acute Myelopathy plan (focused on acute/subacute emergency presentations) and the Cervical Spondylotic Myelopathy plan (focused on degenerative cervical spine disease). This template is designed as a starting framework for any patient with suspected myelopathy where the etiology is uncertain.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Infection screen (abscess, osteomyelitis); baseline; leukocytosis may indicate infectious etiology; anemia may suggest B12 deficiency or malignancy
Renal/hepatic function for contrast administration and medication dosing; electrolytes; glucose for diabetic neuropathy risk
Markedly elevated (>20) in >95% of epidural abscesses; elevated in inflammatory, autoimmune, and neoplastic etiologies; useful screening marker
Elevated in infection and active inflammation; more specific than ESR for acute infection; useful for monitoring treatment response
Coagulopathy as cause of epidural hematoma; pre-LP safety assessment; pre-surgical assessment if emergent decompression needed
Diabetes as risk factor for epidural abscess; diabetic myelopathy (rare); baseline before steroid therapy
UTI as bacteremic source for epidural abscess; baseline bladder function assessment; hematuria may suggest renal malignancy
Potential need for emergent surgical decompression; PLEX preparation
Subacute combined degeneration (posterior columns + corticospinal tracts); common and reversible if caught early
Hypothyroid myelopathy (rare); thyroid dysfunction affects neurologic function and recovery

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Confirms functional B12 deficiency when B12 borderline (200-400 pg/mL); more sensitive than B12 alone
Copper deficiency myelopathy mimics B12 deficiency (posterior columns + corticospinal tracts); associated with gastric surgery, zinc excess, denture cream use
Low with copper deficiency; Wilson disease screen (low ceruloplasmin + high urine copper)
Zinc excess causes copper deficiency via competitive absorption
NMOSD — longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis (LETM >=3 segments); critical for treatment selection (avoid interferon-beta, fingolimod)
MOGAD — often presents as myelitis with conus predilection; treatment and prognosis differ from MS and NMOSD
HIV-associated vacuolar myelopathy; HIV increases risk of opportunistic infections causing myelitis
Syphilitic myelitis (tabes dorsalis — posterior column involvement); neurosyphilis can cause myelopathy
HTLV-associated myelopathy/tropical spastic paraparesis (HAM/TSP); slowly progressive spastic paraparesis
Sjogren syndrome myelitis; may present as chronic progressive or relapsing myelopathy
Neurosarcoidosis — spinal cord granulomas with dorsal subpial enhancement pattern
Spinal tuberculosis (Pott disease); TB myelitis; particularly in endemic populations or immunocompromised
If epidural abscess or hematogenous infection suspected; S. aureus most common organism
Differentiates bacterial infection from inflammatory causes; more specific than CRP for bacterial etiology
Chronic glycemic control assessment; diabetes as risk factor for infection and metabolic myelopathy

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Paraneoplastic myelitis (lung, breast, lymphoma); amphiphysin is classic for stiff-person/paraneoplastic myelopathy
GFAP astrocytopathy — autoimmune meningoencephalomyelitis; radial perivascular enhancement on MRI

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: Antiphospholipid antibodies (lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin, beta2-glycoprotein I)
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Hypercoagulable state causing spinal cord infarction; antiphospholipid syndrome
Multiple myeloma (cord compression from plasmacytoma); POEMS syndrome; Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia
Lyme myelitis — endemic areas; Borrelia burgdorferi infection can cause myelitis
CMV myelitis in immunocompromised patients (HIV/AIDS, transplant recipients)
VZV myelitis — may follow shingles by days to weeks; consider in elderly or immunocompromised
Spinal cord infarction in sickle cell disease from vaso-occlusive crisis
Combined B12/folate deficiency causing myelopathy; may coexist with B12 deficiency
Vitamin E deficiency myelopathy — posterior column dysfunction; associated with malabsorption syndromes
Toxic myelopathy from heavy metal exposure — occupational or environmental

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Elevated in some inflammatory conditions; intracranial hypertension can coexist
Pleocytosis pattern differentiates etiology: mild lymphocytic (MS), moderate with neutrophils (NMOSD), marked (infection), eosinophils (parasitic)
Elevated in GBS, infection, NMOSD, cord compression, malignancy; very high (>100) suggests infection or malignancy
Low CSF:serum ratio (<0.6) in TB, bacterial, fungal, leptomeningeal malignancy
Positive in >90% of MS; may be positive in NMOSD, sarcoidosis, chronic infections
Elevated in MS and other inflammatory CNS conditions
NMOSD confirmation; serum is more sensitive but CSF adds specificity
Leptomeningeal carcinomatosis; CNS lymphoma; may require repeat LP (sensitivity 50% first tap, 80% second)
Neurosyphilis — specific but insensitive (30-70%); confirm with FTA-ABS if high suspicion
HSV myelitis (rare but treatable); ascending myelitis with sacral predilection
VZV myelitis — may follow dermatomal zoster by days to weeks
Spinal tuberculosis — culture takes weeks; smear has low sensitivity

Essential/First-line.item: MRI entire spine (cervical, thoracic, lumbar) with and without gadolinium contrast (CPT 72156+72157+72158)
Essential/First-line.timing: IMMEDIATELY if acute/progressive deficit; within 24-48h if chronic/stable presentation. Entire spine required because multifocal lesions change differential (NMOSD, metastatic disease, sarcoidosis)
Essential/First-line.target: Compressive: epidural mass, disc herniation, stenosis, hematoma. Non-compressive: cord T2 hyperintensity, enhancement pattern, longitudinal extent, cord cross-section location
Essential/First-line.contraindications: GFR <30 (give contrast anyway if emergent); gadolinium allergy (premedicate); pacemaker/MRI-incompatible implants

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24h of spine MRI (same session preferred); essential for identifying concurrent brain lesions
Essential/First-line.target: MS (periventricular/juxtacortical/infratentorial lesions), NMOSD (area postrema, periependymal), ADEM (multifocal white matter), metastatic disease, leptomeningeal enhancement

Essential/First-line.timing: ONLY if MRI unavailable or contraindicated; far less sensitive for cord parenchymal pathology; good for bony anatomy
Essential/First-line.target: Fracture, bony canal narrowing, large epidural mass, disc herniation, vertebral body destruction, OPLL

Essential/First-line.timing: Baseline; lung malignancy screening (metastatic cord compression); sarcoidosis (bilateral hilar adenopathy); TB (apical infiltrates)

Essential/First-line.item: X-ray cervical spine with flexion-extension views (CPT 72052)
Essential/First-line.timing: If degenerative myelopathy suspected; assess dynamic instability; spondylolisthesis

Extended.timing: If metastatic cord compression or sarcoidosis suspected; occult malignancy search
If spinal cord infarction suspected (especially post-aortic surgery, hypotension, aortic pathology)
Extended.target: Aortic dissection; aortic aneurysm; occlusion of artery of Adamkiewicz territory

Extended.timing: Spinal dural arteriovenous fistula (dAVF); spinal AVM — older male with progressive myelopathy and flow voids on MRI
Extended.target: Abnormal vascular flow voids; fistula identification; AVM nidus

Extended.timing: Differentiate myelopathy from peripheral neuropathy or motor neuron disease; identify concurrent radiculopathy; GBS mimicking myelopathy
Extended.target: Normal peripheral nerves in pure myelopathy; peripheral nerve involvement suggests alternative/concurrent diagnosis

Extended.timing: Occult malignancy search when metastatic cord compression suspected but primary unknown
At 2-4 weeks for treatment response assessment; earlier if clinical worsening despite treatment
Extended.target: Improving T2 signal; resolving enhancement; stable or reduced cord swelling

Rare/Specialized.timing: Gold standard for spinal dAVF/AVM when MRA suggestive; required for pre-operative planning
Rare/Specialized.target: Fistula or AVM identification and localization

Rare/Specialized.timing: Assess dorsal column (posterior column) function; objective measure of sensory pathway integrity; prognostication
Rare/Specialized.target: Delayed or absent cortical potentials indicating posterior column dysfunction

Rare/Specialized.timing: Corticospinal tract functional assessment; surgical planning; prognosis
If chronic steroid therapy anticipated (inflammatory myelopathy requiring prolonged immunosuppression); osteoporosis risk

Acute/Emergent.indication: Empiric treatment for suspected inflammatory/demyelinating myelopathy when MRI shows non-compressive cord lesion with T2 hyperintensity and/or enhancement

doseOptions.orderSentence: IV methylprednisolone (empiric — inflammatory myelitis) 1000 mg daily x 3-5 days IV

dosing.instructions: 1000 mg IV daily for 3-5 days; infuse over 1-2 hours. Start empirically if inflammatory myelitis suspected on MRI. Do NOT wait for antibody results

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Active untreated infection (relative — treat infection concurrently if needed); uncontrolled diabetes (relative); active GI bleeding; psychosis
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Glucose q6h; blood pressure q6h; GI prophylaxis with PPI; monitor for insomnia, psychosis, hyperglycemia; taper plan

Acute/Emergent.indication: Compressive myelopathy with neurologic deficit: epidural abscess, tumor with cord compression, acute disc herniation, epidural hematoma

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology consultation for myelopathy diagnostic workup direction, etiology determination, and immunotherapy decisions
Neurosurgery consultation for compressive myelopathy (abscess, tumor, hematoma, disc herniation) — surgical timing critical for outcome
Spine surgery (orthopedic) consultation when neurosurgery unavailable for compressive etiologies requiring decompression
Neuro-immunology (if available) for inflammatory/demyelinating myelopathy requiring disease-modifying therapy decisions (MS, NMOSD, MOGAD)
Radiation oncology for metastatic epidural cord compression requiring urgent radiation planning
Medical oncology for newly diagnosed malignancy identified during myelopathy workup; systemic treatment planning
Infectious disease for epidural abscess management, spinal TB, HIV-associated myelopathy, and atypical infections
Physical therapy for mobility assessment, strengthening program, gait training, transfer training, and assistive device evaluation
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment, upper extremity function optimization, adaptive equipment, and home modification planning
Rehabilitation medicine (physiatry) for comprehensive rehabilitation planning, SCI rehabilitation protocols, functional goal setting, and disposition planning
Urology for neurogenic bladder management, urodynamic testing, and intermittent catheterization training
Respiratory therapy for cervical myelopathy with respiratory muscle weakness; FVC monitoring; ventilator management if needed
Social work for discharge planning, DME coordination, caregiver support, insurance authorization, and disability resources
Pain management for neuropathic pain refractory to gabapentin/pregabalin and standard oral agents
Psychology/psychiatry for adjustment disorder, depression, and coping with disability related to myelopathy-associated functional loss

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately if new or worsening weakness, spreading numbness, loss of bowel or bladder control, inability to walk, or difficulty breathing develops (may indicate disease progression requiring emergent intervention)

Myelopathy has many causes with different prognoses — inflammatory causes often improve with treatment; vascular causes depend on early recognition; degenerative causes may stabilize or improve with surgery
Bladder management is essential: perform intermittent catheterization exactly as instructed; report new urinary retention, incontinence, or signs of UTI (fever, cloudy urine, burning)
Bowel program compliance is critical: maintain regular schedule, adequate fiber (25-30 g/day), and adequate fluid intake (2 L/day unless fluid restricted)
Skin checks twice daily: inspect pressure areas (sacrum, heels, elbows) for redness or breakdown; reposition every 2 hours if immobile; use pressure-relieving mattress
Do NOT drive until cleared by neurology due to risk of lower extremity weakness, sensory loss, or spasticity causing impaired vehicle control
Do NOT stop steroid medications abruptly as this may cause adrenal crisis; follow prescribed taper schedule exactly
Perform prescribed physical therapy exercises between sessions as instructed to maximize neurologic recovery
Follow-up with neurology in 1-2 weeks after discharge; repeat MRI at 2-4 weeks to assess treatment response

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Pressure injury prevention with specialized mattress, q2h repositioning, and daily skin assessment for immobilized patients
Fall prevention program including assistive device evaluation (cane, walker, wheelchair), home safety assessment, removal of trip hazards, and bathroom modifications
DVT prevention long-term with compression stockings when ambulatory; maintain adequate hydration; avoid prolonged immobility

Autonomic dysreflexia awareness education for patients with thoracic or cervical cord lesions: recognize sudden hypertension, headache, flushing above level as emergency requiring immediate removal of stimulus (distended bladder, bowel impaction, skin irritation)
Smoking cessation to reduce vascular risk, improve wound healing, and optimize surgical outcomes if surgery indicated

Vaccination completion before starting immunosuppressive therapy: influenza (annual), pneumococcal, hepatitis B, meningococcal (if eculizumab planned), COVID-19; avoid live vaccines within 4 weeks of immunosuppression
Bone health optimization if chronic steroid therapy anticipated: calcium 1000-1200 mg/day + vitamin D 1000-2000 IU/day; DEXA scan at baseline if steroid use >3 months anticipated
Mental health support referral given high rates of depression and anxiety following spinal cord injury and chronic myelopathy (30-40% prevalence)
Regular low-impact exercise program (aquatic therapy, stationary cycling, seated exercises) to maintain cardiovascular fitness and prevent deconditioning without exacerbating spasticity

differential.features: Back pain + fever + neurologic deficit (classic triad in 10-15%); IVDU, diabetes, spinal procedure, bacteremia risk factors; ESR/CRP markedly elevated
differential.tests: MRI with contrast (ring-enhancing epidural collection); blood cultures; ESR >20 in 95%; surgical drainage + antibiotics

differential.features: Known malignancy or weight loss; progressive back pain worse at night and supine; bony destruction; may be multi-level
differential.tests: MRI entire spine (enhancing epidural mass with bony changes); CT body for primary; PET-CT; SPEP

differential.features: Sudden onset; often cervical or thoracic level; radiculopathy predominates initially; may progress to cord compression
differential.tests: MRI (disc protrusion with cord compression); usually degenerative history

differential.features: Anticoagulation; post-procedure (LP, epidural); coagulopathy; sudden severe back pain with progressive deficit
differential.tests: MRI (epidural collection; T1 signal varies with blood age); coagulation panel; reversal of anticoagulation

differential.features: Partial myelitis (<3 segments); eccentric/dorsolateral; brain lesions present; prior episodes; young female predominance; relapsing-remitting course
differential.tests: MRI brain (periventricular/juxtacortical/infratentorial lesions); CSF oligoclonal bands; short segment (<3) cord lesion

differential.features: Longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis (LETM >=3 segments); central cord/gray matter; severe; optic neuritis history; area postrema syndrome
differential.tests: AQP4-IgG antibody (cell-based assay); MRI (LETM, central cord pattern); brain MRI (area postrema lesion)

differential.features: LETM possible; conus/lower cord predilection; bilateral optic neuritis; cortical encephalitis; often younger; generally better recovery than NMOSD
differential.tests: MOG-IgG antibody (cell-based assay); MRI pattern; may have brain lesions distinct from MS

differential.features: Non-compressive; T2 cord signal change; may be partial or complete; often thoracic; diagnosis of exclusion after ruling out MS, NMOSD, MOGAD, infection
differential.tests: MRI (T2 hyperintensity); LP (pleocytosis); negative AQP4, MOG; no brain lesions meeting MS criteria

differential.features: Hyperacute onset (minutes to hours); anterior spinal artery syndrome (motor + pain/temperature loss, preserved proprioception/vibration); often thoracolumbar; risk factors include aortic surgery, atherosclerosis, hypotension
differential.tests: MRI DWI (restricted diffusion); "owl eye" or pencil-like pattern on axial; CTA aorta; echocardiography

differential.features: Older male; slowly progressive myelopathy; flow voids on MRI; dorsal cord location; extensive edema disproportionate to enhancement; may fluctuate with exercise
differential.tests: MRI (flow voids, dorsal cord edema, centromedullary T2 signal); spinal angiography (gold standard); MRA screening

differential.features: Chronic progressive; insidious onset; hand clumsiness + gait imbalance; canal stenosis on imaging; age >50; no inflammatory markers
differential.tests: MRI cervical spine (cord compression from disc/osteophyte/ligament); flexion-extension X-rays; EMG to exclude concurrent radiculopathy

differential.features: Posterior column (proprioception, vibration) + corticospinal tract dysfunction; macrocytic anemia; peripheral neuropathy; dietary risk (vegan, pernicious anemia, gastric surgery)
differential.tests: B12 level; methylmalonic acid (elevated); homocysteine (elevated); MRI (posterior column T2 signal)

differential.features: Pattern identical to B12 deficiency; gastric surgery, zinc excess (denture cream), total parenteral nutrition
differential.tests: Serum copper (low); ceruloplasmin (low); zinc (may be elevated); MRI (posterior column signal change)

differential.features: Dorsal subpial enhancement; "trident sign"; may have pulmonary sarcoidosis, uveitis, cranial neuropathies; relapsing course
differential.tests: Chest CT (hilar adenopathy); ACE level (serum and CSF); biopsy if accessible; characteristic MRI pattern

differential.features: Progressive; expansile cord lesion; ependymoma (central, hemorrhagic caps), astrocytoma (eccentric, infiltrative); hemangioblastoma (enhancing nodule with cyst)
differential.tests: MRI with contrast (enhancing intramedullary mass); surgical biopsy/resection; CSF cytology

differential.features: Combined upper and lower motor neuron signs WITHOUT sensory involvement; fasciculations; bulbar symptoms; progressive weakness
differential.tests: EMG (widespread denervation); MRI normal cord parenchyma; clinical examination (no sensory level)

differential.features: Posterior column dysfunction (proprioception, vibration loss); lightning pains; Argyll Robertson pupils; long latency after primary infection
differential.tests: CSF VDRL; serum RPR; FTA-ABS; treatable with IV penicillin

differential.features: Slowly progressive spastic paraparesis; bladder dysfunction; endemic areas (Japan, Caribbean, Africa); HTLV-1 seropositivity
differential.tests: HTLV-1/2 antibody (serum and CSF); proviral load

differential.features: Non-anatomic sensory loss; Hoover sign; give-way weakness; inconsistent exam findings; normal MRI and LP; positive clinical signs of functional disorder
differential.tests: Normal MRI; normal LP; normal evoked potentials; clinical exam demonstrates positive functional signs

evidence.recommendation: MRI entire spine with contrast as first-line diagnostic study for myelopathy; sensitivity >95% for cord compression and intrinsic cord lesions
evidence.source: [Defined diagnostic criteria for myelopathy, Transverse Myelitis Consortium Working Group 2002](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12236201/)

evidence.recommendation: IV methylprednisolone 1g/day x 3-5 days for acute inflammatory myelitis; start empirically without waiting for antibody results
evidence.source: Consensus; extrapolated from MS relapse data; [Beck et al. ONTT (NEJM 1992)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/1339245/)

evidence.recommendation: PLEX for steroid-refractory inflammatory myelitis (5-7 exchanges)
AQP4-IgG cell-based assay for NMOSD diagnosis; serum preferred over CSF (higher sensitivity)
MOG-IgG for MOGAD diagnosis and distinction from MS and NMOSD; treatment implications differ significantly
Surgical decompression within 24h for compressive myelopathy improves neurologic outcomes; earlier decompression associated with better recovery
B12 deficiency causing subacute combined degeneration is reversible with early replacement; IM preferred initially for reliable absorption
Eculizumab reduces relapse risk in AQP4-IgG-positive NMOSD by 94% compared to placebo
Spinal dural AV fistula requires conventional angiography (DSA) for definitive diagnosis; MRI may show flow voids and cord edema but is insufficient for surgical planning
evidence.source: Defined diagnostic approach for spinal vascular malformations; Defined Standards 2015

evidence.recommendation: DVT prophylaxis mandatory in immobilized myelopathy patients; SCI patients have 50-80% DVT rate without prophylaxis
Copper deficiency myelopathy mimics B12 deficiency and is reversible with supplementation; zinc excess is a common treatable cause
Rituximab effective for NMOSD relapse prevention; non-inferior to azathioprine with faster onset of action
evidence.source: [Tahara et al. 2020; Multiple retrospective and prospective studies](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32123063/)

evidence.recommendation: LP should be performed AFTER MRI in myelopathy to avoid LP through epidural abscess (risk of meningitis) and to guide CSF study selection based on imaging pattern
evidence.source: Expert consensus; risk of infection seeding through abscess documented in case series

monitoring.item: Neurologic exam (strength, sensory level, reflexes, rectal tone)
monitoring.frequency: q4h x 48h, then q8h inpatient; each clinic visit outpatient; mark sensory level on skin for tracking
monitoring.action: If ascending sensory level or worsening motor exam: STAT repeat MRI; escalate treatment (PLEX if on steroids); neurosurgery if compressive

monitoring.frequency: PVR with each void initially; I/O daily inpatient; PVR at each clinic visit
monitoring.action: If PVR 200-500 mL: intermittent catheterization q4-6h; if PVR >500 mL: Foley catheter; urology referral

monitoring.frequency: q4-6h if cervical cord involvement; q2h if declining; each clinic visit if chronic
monitoring.action: If FVC <20 mL/kg or NIF less negative than -30: ICU transfer; prepare for intubation; respiratory therapy STAT

monitoring.frequency: q4h inpatient; orthostatic vitals when mobilizing; each clinic visit
monitoring.action: If orthostatic: volume resuscitation; compression stockings; midodrine; if hypertensive crisis above lesion level: autonomic dysreflexia protocol (find and remove stimulus)
If febrile: infection workup (blood cultures, UA, chest X-ray, wound check); consider UTI (most common); line infection; abscess progression

monitoring.frequency: q6h while on IV methylprednisolone; daily on oral prednisone; HbA1c at 3 months if prolonged steroids
monitoring.action: Insulin sliding scale; endocrine consultation if persistent hyperglycemia; steroid taper optimization

monitoring.frequency: Every shift inpatient; at every repositioning; each clinic visit
monitoring.action: Pressure relief; specialty mattress; wound care consultation; Braden scale assessment

monitoring.frequency: q48-72h during active treatment; weekly until normalized
monitoring.action: If not improving: reassess antibiotic coverage; repeat imaging for persistent collection; surgical drainage if not performed

monitoring.frequency: At 2-4 weeks; 3-6 months; 12 months; or earlier if clinical worsening
monitoring.action: If worsening: escalate treatment (add PLEX if on steroids alone); reassess diagnosis; repeat LP; consider biopsy if diagnostic uncertainty

monitoring.frequency: Per agent-specific protocol: CD19/20 q3-6 months (rituximab); immunoglobulins q6 months; CBC per protocol
monitoring.action: If inadequate depletion: redose early; if hypogammaglobulinemia: IVIG replacement consideration; if cytopenias: hold agent and reassess

disposition.criteria: Mild myelopathy with stable exam; ambulatory independently or with assistive device; independent bladder function (PVR <200); complete workup OR reliable outpatient follow-up for pending studies; MRI completed; adequate pain control; home support available

Non-compressive myelopathy requiring IV steroids; moderate motor deficits (MRC 3-4/5); bladder dysfunction requiring catheterization; workup incomplete and etiology uncertain; need for LP; progressive symptoms requiring monitoring

Cervical myelopathy with respiratory compromise (FVC <20 mL/kg); ascending myelopathy with rapidly progressing deficits; autonomic instability; post-surgical monitoring; severe quadriparesis requiring continuous monitoring
Compressive myelopathy with neurologic deficit: epidural abscess, acute tumor compression, epidural hematoma, acute disc herniation with cord compression — consult neurosurgery STAT

disposition.disposition: Transfer to higher level of care
disposition.criteria: Need for neurosurgery not available at current facility; need for PLEX not available; MRI not available on STAT basis; spinal cord injury center for comprehensive SCI rehabilitation; neuro-immunology expertise needed

Significant motor deficits (paraparesis, quadriparesis); wheelchair-dependent or requires assistive device; bladder/bowel dysfunction requiring ongoing management; able to participate in >=3 hours/day of therapy; medically stable
Unable to tolerate intensive inpatient rehabilitation (less than 3 hours/day); requires skilled nursing care; ongoing IV antibiotics; stable but unable to return home safely
